Situation1: They attend a local workshop on updated prescription guidelines to ensure proper patient counseling.
Expectation2: Leading the daily prayers in the mosque
Situation2: The regular backup is away, so most congregants expect him to step forward for the scheduled prayer.
Story: I sat in the back row of the community center, notebook open, listening intently as the speaker explained the latest prescription guidelines. As a pharmacist, I knew how crucial it was to stay updated—patients depended on me for safe, accurate advice. My phone buzzed quietly in my pocket. A message from the mosque committee flashed on the screen: “Backup imam is out of town. Can you lead Maghrib prayer tonight? Everyone is expecting you.” My heart tightened. The workshop was scheduled to run late, but the congregation would be waiting, looking to me for spiritual guidance. I imagined the disappointment if I didn’t show up, the trust they placed in me as their imam. Yet, missing this workshop meant falling behind in my professional duties, possibly putting patients at risk. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my presence, each vital in its own way. I stared at my phone, torn, the clock ticking toward both obligations.
